pythagoras-node-1.title: Identifying the Hypotenuse
learningFocus: Identify the hypotenuse in different triangle orientations
Understand hypotenuse is opposite the right angle
Recognize hypotenuse as the longest side

exemplarProblems.problemText: In the right-angled triangle shown, which side is the hypotenuse?
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: AB (or the longest side opposite the right angle)

exemplarProblems.problemText: Triangle PQR has a right angle at Q. Which side is the hypotenuse?
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: PR (the side opposite the right angle)

questionFormats: Identify the hypotenuse in this triangle
Name the longest side of this right-angled triangle

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE question per problem. Do NOT create multi-part questions.
CRITICAL: Include mathTool showing triangle structure - helps understanding WITHOUT revealing answer
Use different vertex label combinations for variety
Vary triangle orientation (rotate which corner has right angle)
Keep side labels simple (single letters or short values like '5 cm', '12 m')
Ensure the triangle diagram shows clear right angle marker
Question should ask student to identify which side is hypotenuse
Accept answers in form 'AB', 'side AB', or description 'longest side'

pythagoras-node-2.title: Verifying Pythagorean Triples
learningFocus: State Pythagoras' Theorem: a² + b² = c²
Verify that three numbers form a Pythagorean triple
Recognize common triples: 3-4-5, 5-12-13, 8-15-17, 7-24-25

exemplarProblems.problemText: Does the set of numbers {3, 4, 5} satisfy Pythagoras' Theorem? Show your working.
A triangle has sides 5 cm, 12 cm and 13 cm. Verify whether these satisfy a² + b² = c².
Do the numbers 7, 24, and 25 form a Pythagorean triple?

questionFormats: Verify whether {a, b, c} satisfy Pythagoras' Theorem
Do the numbers a, b, and c form a Pythagorean triple?
A triangle has sides a, b, and c. Check if a² + b² = c²
Does the set {a, b, c} satisfy a² + b² = c²?

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE question per problem asking to verify the triple
CRITICAL: DO NOT include mathTool - showing the triangle would reveal if it's right-angled
Mix Pythagorean triples (which satisfy) with non-triples (which don't)
Use 70% actual triples and 30% non-triples for variety
Present numbers in random order (not always smallest to largest)
Require students to show working: identify c as largest, then check a² + b² = c²
Accept both 'Yes, satisfies' and calculation showing equality
Include units occasionally (cm, m) but keep numbers manageable

pythagoras-node-3.title: Finding the Hypotenuse - Exact Answers
learningFocus: Apply c² = a² + b² to find the hypotenuse
Calculate c = √(a² + b²)
Recognize Pythagorean triples for exact answers

exemplarProblems.problemText: A right-angled triangle has legs of length 3 cm and 4 cm. Find the length of the hypotenuse.
In triangle ABC with right angle at C, AC = 5 m and BC = 12 m. Calculate the length of AB.
The two shorter sides of a right-angled triangle are 8 cm and 15 cm. Find the hypotenuse.

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE question per problem - find the hypotenuse only
CRITICAL: Include mathTool showing ONLY the two legs (opposite and adjacent)
DO NOT show hypotenuse value in mathTool - that would reveal the answer!
Use Pythagorean triples exclusively for this node (exact answers)
Vary presentation: 'legs of length 3 and 4' vs 'AC = 5, BC = 12'
Keep numbers reasonable (legs under 30 for basic triples)
Always include units in the question and require units in answer
Students should state final answer as 'c cm' not just the number
Rotate through different triples for variety
In mathTool, set caption to describe the triangle context

pythagoras-node-4.title: Finding the Hypotenuse - Decimal Answers
learningFocus: Calculate hypotenuse for non-Pythagorean triples
Use calculator to find square roots
Round answers to 1 dp, 2 dp, or 3 sf as specified

exemplarProblems.problemText: A right-angled triangle has legs of 7 cm and 9 cm. Find the hypotenuse to 1 decimal place.
In triangle PQR with right angle at R, PR = 11 m and QR = 8 m. Calculate PQ to 2 decimal places.

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE question per problem
CRITICAL: Include mathTool showing the two legs only (NOT hypotenuse)
Use non-Pythagorean pairs (not exact square roots)
Explicitly state rounding requirement in question
Vary between 1 dp, 2 dp, and 3 sf
Keep leg values between 5 and 20 for manageable calculations
Always include units in question and expected answer
Students must use calculator for √ calculation
Answer should be rounded as specified, with units

pythagoras-node-5.title: Finding the Hypotenuse - Word Problems
learningFocus: Identify right-angled triangle in word problems
Extract relevant measurements from context
Apply Pythagoras to find hypotenuse in real situations

exemplarProblems.problemText: A ladder of length x metres is placed against a wall. The base of the ladder is 3 m from the wall and reaches 4 m up the wall. Find the length of the ladder.
A rectangular garden is 12 m long and 5 m wide. Find the length of the diagonal path across the garden.

ladder.description: A ladder is placed against a wall. The base is {distance} from the wall and reaches {height} up the wall.
ladder.question: Find the length of the ladder

diagonal.description: A rectangle is {length} long and {width} wide.
diagonal.question: Find the length of the diagonal

kite.description: A kite is flying with {horizontal} of string out horizontally and risen {vertical} vertically.
kite.question: Find the total length of string from the person to the kite

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE question per problem
CRITICAL: DO NOT include mathTool initially - let student visualize the triangle
Use realistic contexts: ladders, rectangles, kites, TV screens
Question should describe scenario and ask for ONE unknown length
Use Pythagorean triples for easier calculation (this is still foundational practice)
Include units appropriate to context (m for ladders, cm for screens)
Student must: 1) Identify the right triangle, 2) Label known values, 3) Calculate hypotenuse
Accept answers with or without working, as long as final answer is correct with units

pythagoras-node-6.title: Finding a Shorter Side - Using c² - b²
learningFocus: Rearrange a² + b² = c² to find a leg: a² = c² - b²
Apply a = √(c² - b²) correctly
Distinguish finding hypotenuse from finding a leg

exemplarProblems.problemText: In a right-angled triangle, the hypotenuse is 13 cm and one leg is 5 cm. Find the length of the other leg.
Triangle PQR has a right angle at Q. PQ = 15 m and PR = 17 m. Find the length of QR.

questionFormats: hypotenuse is {c}, one leg is {b}, find the other leg
right angle at Q, PQ = {b}, PR = {c}, find QR

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE question per problem - find ONE unknown leg
CRITICAL: Include mathTool showing hypotenuse and ONE known leg (NOT the unknown leg)
DO NOT show the unknown leg value in mathTool - that reveals the answer!
Always identify which side is the hypotenuse (use c as largest value)
Use Pythagorean triples for exact answers (no decimals in this foundational node)
Vary which leg is given vs unknown
Emphasize: 'hypotenuse is...' to make it clear which is c
Student must recognize to use a² = c² - b², not c² = a² + b²
Expected process: Square hypotenuse, square known leg, subtract, take square root
Include units in question and require units in answer

pythagoras-node-7.title: Finding a Leg - Decimal Answers
learningFocus: Apply a = √(c² - b²) for non-Pythagorean values
Use calculator and round appropriately
Verify answer makes sense (leg must be shorter than hypotenuse)

exemplarProblems.problemText: A right-angled triangle has hypotenuse 20 cm and one leg 11 cm. Find the other leg to 1 decimal place.

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE question per problem
CRITICAL: Include mathTool showing hypotenuse and known leg only
Use non-Pythagorean values requiring calculator
Always specify rounding precision
Ensure hypotenuse is clearly the longest value
Keep values manageable (c < 35, b < 25)
Students must: identify c, identify given leg b, calculate √(c² - b²)
Verify student understands this is DIFFERENT from finding hypotenuse

pythagoras-node-8.title: Finding a Leg - Word Problems
learningFocus: Identify when hypotenuse is given in word problems
Extract measurements and determine unknown leg
Apply a² = c² - b² in real contexts

exemplarProblems.problemText: A 10 m ladder leans against a wall and reaches 8 m up the wall. How far is the base of the ladder from the wall?
A rectangle has diagonal 15 cm and length 9 cm. Find the width of the rectangle.

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE question per problem
CRITICAL: DO NOT include mathTool - let student identify triangle from context
Use contexts where hypotenuse is explicitly stated: 'ladder length', 'diagonal'
Question provides hypotenuse and ONE other side, asks for the third
Use Pythagorean triples for easier verification
Student must: 1) Identify hypotenuse, 2) Identify given leg, 3) Calculate using c² - b²
Common error: Students may add instead of subtract - question should prompt correct thinking
Include realistic units appropriate to context

pythagoras-node-9.title: Ladder and Navigation Problems
learningFocus: Identify right-angled triangles in real contexts
Apply Pythagoras to ladder problems (wall-ground-ladder)
Calculate navigation distances with perpendicular directions

exemplarProblems.problemText: A 15 m ladder is placed 9 m from the base of a wall. How high up the wall does the ladder reach?
A person walks 8 km north, then 6 km east. How far are they from their starting point in a straight line?

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE question per problem
CRITICAL: DO NOT include mathTool - student should visualize triangle from description
For ladder: always form right triangle (ground, wall, ladder)
For navigation: perpendicular directions (north-south, east-west) form right angle
Use Pythagorean triples for easier mental verification
Question should describe realistic scenario
Student must: 1) Draw diagram, 2) Identify right triangle, 3) Apply Pythagoras
Vary what is being found: height, base distance, or hypotenuse
Include appropriate units (m for ladders, km for navigation)
Accept answers with units and reasonable rounding if needed

pythagoras-node-10.title: Rectangle Diagonal Problems
learningFocus: Apply Pythagoras to find rectangle diagonals
Use formula d² = l² + w²
Solve practical problems (TV screens, tables, fields)

exemplarProblems.problemText: A rectangular TV screen is 80 cm wide and 45 cm high. Find the diagonal length of the screen to 1 decimal place.
A rectangular garden is 12 m long and 5 m wide. Calculate the length of the diagonal path across the garden.

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE question per problem - find the diagonal only
CRITICAL: Include mathTool showing rectangle with length and width labeled
DO NOT show diagonal in mathTool - student must calculate it
Use realistic contexts: TV screens, gardens, tables, fields
Mix exact answers (Pythagorean triples) with decimal answers
For non-triples, specify rounding precision
Question gives length and width, asks for diagonal
Students apply d² = l² + w² or recognize it's Pythagoras on the rectangle
Include appropriate units for context (cm for screens, m for gardens)

pythagoras-node-11.title: 3D Space Diagonals - Cuboids
learningFocus: Apply Pythagoras twice for 3D problems
Calculate base diagonal first, then space diagonal
Use formula d² = l² + w² + h² or two-step method

exemplarProblems.problemText: A box measures 12 cm long, 9 cm wide, and 8 cm high. Find the length of the space diagonal (from one corner to the opposite corner through the interior).
A room is 5 m long, 4 m wide, and 3 m high. Calculate the straight-line distance from one bottom corner to the opposite top corner to 1 decimal place.

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE question per problem - find space diagonal only
CRITICAL: Include mathTool showing cuboid with dimensions labeled
DO NOT show space diagonal in mathTool parameters - set showSpaceDiagonal: false
Question provides all three dimensions (length, width, height)
Students must apply Pythagoras TWICE:
Step 1: Find base diagonal using √(l² + w²)
Step 2: Use base diagonal with height: √((base diagonal)² + h²)
Alternatively: Use direct formula d = √(l² + w² + h²)
Mix exact answers with decimal answers requiring rounding
Use realistic contexts: boxes, rooms, containers
Include appropriate units
This is advanced - expect students to need guidance on two-step approach

pythagoras-node-12.title: Testing for Right Triangles - Converse
learningFocus: State the converse: IF a² + b² = c², THEN triangle is right-angled
Test if given sides form a right triangle
Identify longest side as c before testing

exemplarProblems.problemText: A triangle has sides 7 cm, 24 cm, and 25 cm. Determine whether this is a right-angled triangle. Show your working.
Does a triangle with sides 10 m, 11 m, and 12 m contain a right angle?
Three sides of a triangle are 5, 12, and 13. Use the converse of Pythagoras' Theorem to check if it has a right angle.

questionFormats: Determine whether this is a right-angled triangle
Does this triangle contain a right angle?
Use the converse to check if it has a right angle
Is this a right-angled triangle? Show your working

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE question per problem - test ONE set of sides
CRITICAL: DO NOT include mathTool initially - would reveal if triangle is right-angled
Mix right triangles (60-70%) with non-right triangles (30-40%)
Present sides in random order (not always ascending)
Students must: 1) Identify longest side as c, 2) Calculate a² + b², 3) Calculate c², 4) Compare
Require working to be shown, not just yes/no answer
Accept format: 'Yes, because 3² + 4² = 25 = 5²' or similar
Emphasize the CONVERSE: testing IF sides satisfy the relationship
Use exact Pythagorean triples or clear non-triples (avoid ambiguous near-misses)

pythagoras-node-13.title: Construction Checking - 3-4-5 Method
learningFocus: Apply converse in construction contexts
Understand 3-4-5 rope method creates right angles
Verify corners are square using measurements

exemplarProblems.problemText: A carpenter measures 90 cm along one edge and 120 cm along another edge. The diagonal measures 150 cm. Is the corner square (90°)? Use the converse of Pythagoras' Theorem.
To check if a wall corner is right-angled, measurements of 6 m, 8 m, and 10 m are used. Verify if this forms a 90° angle.
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: Yes. 6² + 8² = 36 + 64 = 100 = 10². This forms a right angle.

exemplarProblems.problemText: Ancient Egyptians used a rope with 12 equally-spaced knots to form a triangle with sides of 3, 4, and 5 units. Explain why this creates a right angle.
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: Because 3² + 4² = 9 + 16 = 25 = 5². By the converse of Pythagoras' Theorem, this forms a right-angled triangle with the right angle opposite the longest side.

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE question per problem
CRITICAL: DO NOT include mathTool - context is about construction checking
Use multiples of 3-4-5 triangle (most practical for construction)
Present in practical contexts: carpentry, construction, gardening
Question provides three measurements and asks to verify right angle
Students must: 1) Recognize this is converse application, 2) Check if a² + b² = c²
Include units appropriate to construction (cm, m)
Emphasize practical application: ensuring corners are square
All provided measurements should form valid right triangles (this is about verification, not testing non-right cases)
Historical context (Egyptian rope) can be included for enrichment
